'''''Feuer und Flamme''''' (German for "Fire and Flame", with the additional figurative meaning of "great enthusiasm"), released in 1985, is the third album by German pop band [[Nena (band)|Nena]] and the fourth studio album of its singer, [[Nena|Gabriele "Nena" Kerner]].<ref>[http://www.nena.de/de/discografie/feuer-und-flamme ''Feuer und Flamme''] at the official Nena website, with complete lyrics and samples for music. Retrieved 27 October 2017.</ref> The album was a success, reaching {{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}2}} in Germany.<ref name="Stürenburg2001">{{cite book|author=Holger Stürenburg|title=Forever Young|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gun_R2vNpA4C&pg=PA18|accessdate=3 August 2013|year=2001|publisher=BoD – Books on Demand|language=German|isbn=978-3-8311-1616-4|pages=18–|quote=Als eine Art deutsche Antwort auf Madonna sollte "Feuer und Flamme" der jungen Sängerin weiterhin internationale ... 1986 wurden Nena und ihr im Oktober gleichen Jahres veröffentlichtes Album "Eisbrecher" nur noch unter "ferner liefen" gehandelt. ... Bald darauf gab es neues Material, ebenfalls eine Art New Romantic auf Deutsch: Die Single „Nur mit Dir" (Februar 1985), auf die mit „Verliebte Jungs", ...}}</ref>
Prompted by the success of ''[[99 Luftballons (album)|99 Luftballons]]'' (1984), which included English-language versions of songs from the band's first two albums, Nena recreated ''Feuer und Flamme'' in English as '''''It's All in the Game''''' (1985), with lyrics by Canadian singer [[Lisa Dalbello]].<ref>[http://www.nena.de/de/discografie/its-all-game ''It's All in the Game''] at the official Nena website, with complete lyrics and samples for music. Retrieved 27 October 2017.</ref> The experiment failed commercially and was not repeated with the band's next album. Gabriele Kerner recorded a new bilingual German-English version of "[[Irgendwie, irgendwo, irgendwann#Anyplace, Anywhere, Anytime|Anyplace, Anywhere, Anytime]]" with [[Kim Wilde]] in 2002. The duet became a big hit in many European countries, including Germany, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Switzerland and the Netherlands.
The fifth and final single from the album was "Du kennst die Liebe nicht", however, for the single release, the song was completely re-recorded. The single version was restructured and features different vocals as well as a different instrumental that just sporadically borrows motifs from the album version.<ref>[https://www.nena.de/de/discografie/du-kennst-die-liebe-nicht "Du kennst die Liebe nicht" (single)] at the official Nena website, with complete lyrics and samples for music. Retrieved 22 September 2019.</ref> It was later included on the compilation ''[[Nena die Band (album)|Nena die Band]]'' (1991).<ref>[https://www.nena.de/de/discografie/nena-die-band ''Nena die Band''] at the official Nena website, with complete lyrics and samples for music. Retrieved 22 September 2019.</ref>

The LP edition has tracks 4 and 9 swapped.<ref name="discogs">[http://www.discogs.com/Nena-Feuer-Und-Flamme/master/52193 ''Feuer und Flamme''] at [[Discogs]]. Retrieved 2 October 2014.</ref> Length of track 10 on LP is 5:14 due to the much shorter (partly edited out) instrumental intro. On some CD releases, length of track 3 is 5:09.

Of the bonus tracks on the 2008 reissue,<ref>[http://www.discogs.com/Nena-Its-All-In-The-Game/release/1280362 ''It's All in the Game'', 2008 reissue] (UK, Cherry Pop Records – CR POP 7) at [[Discogs]]. Retrieved 9 October 2014.</ref> "At the Movies" was first released in 1984 as a single coupled with its German original, "Kino", from ''[[Nena (album)|Nena]]'' (1983); "Just a Dream" and "99 Red Balloons" are tracks from ''[[99 Luftballons (album)|99 Luftballons]]'' (1984), here remixed; and the remix of "It's All in the Game" reprises the title track of the present album.
